titlestmt.titleproper: Fussiner (Barbara and Howard) collection on Denise Levertov
Barbara and Howard Fussiner collection on Denise Levertov M2241
titlestmt.author: Malgorzata Schaefer

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-09-12 12:42:27 -0700.

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

did.unittitle: Barbara and Howard Fussiner collection on Denise Levertov

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Barabara (n√©e Bank) Fussiner and her husband Howard Fussiner were friends of poet Denise Levertov. Barbara and Denise met in New York in 1948 through Mitch Goodman's brother Howard. Barbara went on to work as the director of the Children's Preschool in New Haven, Connecticut. Howard was a painter and later worked as Souther Connecticut State University as a professor of art. Denise and Mitch wed in 1947 and divorced in 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials consist of correspondence between the Fussiners and Denise Levertov and Mitchell Goodman, mostly incoming correspondece to the Fussiners from Denise and/or Mitch. Letters and cards from a few other individuals can be found in the collection as well.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Denise also signed her name as Denny, Den, D. She also addressed Barbara and Howard Fussiner as B and H.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased by Stanford Libraries in 2017. Accession 2017-190.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Barbara and Howard Fussiner collection on Denise Levertov (M2241). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Note that material must be requested at least 36 hours in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While Special Collections is the owner of the physical items, permission to examine collection materials is not an authorization to publish. These materials are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study. Any transmission or reproduction beyond that allowed by fair use requires permission from the owners of rights, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/spc/using-collections/permission-publish.
